importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: First reported instance of investigation into SMT's fraudulent practices began in summer 2016, when a personal finance journalist discovered a potential scam targeting timeshare owners.
The BBC Scotland Investigates programme exposing SMT's fraudulent sales tactics was broadcast on this date, leading to increased public awareness and police involvement.
During the first UK Covid-19 lockdown, police informed the BBC of 19 arrests related to SMT, marking a turning point in the legal investigation.
The final criminal proceedings concluded with 14 convictions, including key figures like Mark Rowe and Nicola Rowe, bringing closure to a long-running fraud case.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The fraud and media exposure spanned nearly a decade, from initial investigation in 2016 to the final criminal convictions in 2025.

keyTakeAways: A £28 million timeshare fraud targeting over 3,500 British owners, primarily aged 60–80, was uncovered through BBC secret filming.
The fraud involved a bait-and-switch scheme where victims were sold fake 'Monster Rewards' credits instead of real property resale options.
The company Sell My Timeshare (SMT) used high-pressure sales tactics, including up-front fees and misleading promises of future profits.
Mark Rowe, the top executive, was sentenced to seven-and-a-half years; his wife Nicola received a two-year suspended sentence for money laundering.
The BBC's secret filming in 2016 was pivotal in exposing the fraud and provided critical evidence to law enforcement.
Over 500 victims lost over £10,000, with one losing more than £80,000, and many still legally bound to unusable contracts.
The case represents one of the largest and most well-documented consumer frauds in UK history, with long-term implications for consumer protection.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A £28 million timeshare fraud involving over 3,500 elderly British victims was uncovered through secret filming by BBC Scotland Investigates in 2016. The company Sell My Timeshare (SMT) used a bait-and-switch scheme, misleading owners into paying large upfront fees for non-existent property resale options and instead offering fake 'Monster Rewards' credits. The investigation, led by journalist Fergus Muirhead, revealed that victims—many aged 60 to 80—were subjected to high-pressure sales tactics and left with unusable contracts and significant financial losses. Mark Rowe, the company’s top executive, was sentenced to seven-and-a-half years in prison for conspiracy to defraud, while his wife Nicola received a suspended two-year sentence for money laundering. Nine years after the initial broadcast, 14 individuals were convicted in a series of trials at Southwark Crown Court, and the CPS is now pursuing the recovery of stolen assets. The case represents one of the largest consumer frauds in UK history and underscores the critical role of investigative journalism in exposing corporate misconduct.
title: How BBC secret filming exposed a £28m timeshare fraud
